Approximately 95 percent of a lithium-ion battery can be recycled into new batteries. In fact, the metals used in lithium-ion applications, such as lithium, nickel, and cobalt, hold their value beyond the life of the battery, allowing recycling facilities to reclaim these materials.

Even as he was helping to launch the electric-car revolution, Tesla co-founder J.B. Straubel was thinking about what would ultimately happen to the valuable nickel, cobalt, and lithium in battery packs. Redwood Materials, which he founded in 2017, is helping to create a circular battery economy that shrinks the environmental footprint of EVs. Its proprietary process mines up to 95% of key elements from used batteries, as well as other minerals. 

 In January, Redwood broke ground on its second facility, a $3.5 billion plant in South Carolina. The company received a $2 billion Department of Energy loan, and the substance of Straubel’s vision has attracted many big-name customers, including Ford, Toyota, Volkswagen, Audi, Panasonic, and Lyft.

I disagree. Giving people money they didn't earn leads to inflation. Cutting taxes does not. 

Allow me to explain. There are two components to the economy, supply and demand, and when they operate approximately in balance, life is pretty good. Everyone is consuming things (which is inevitable ... we must have food, shelter and clothing) but nearly everyone is producing things, too. To spend $1, I first have to earn that dollar and thus put a dollar's worth of goods or services back into the economy for someone else to purchase. 

When the government borrows money and gives it to people didn't earn it, it spikes the "demand" side of the teeter-totter. Now people can spend more without necessarily producing more. You wind up with too many dollars chasing too few goods, and that leads to inflation, as sellers are able to raise their prices to vacuum up all of the extra money in circulation. (We saw this happen with food prices after the billions allocated to the SNAP program were doubled between 2019-2023.) 

Letting people keep more of the money they've earned (tax cuts) doesn't have the same effect. It doesn't create "new money" the way borrowing does. The same amount of money is still in circulation; the only differences is that it's being spent by the people who earned it and not the government that confiscated it via taxes.

Let’s get to the root of it—healthcare in America has become an outlier among first-world nations. Most other developed countries provide healthcare to their citizens as a fundamental right, not as a privilege tied to employment. For a society that prides itself on independence and innovation, why have we trapped so many working Americans in jobs solely for benefits like healthcare? This dependency on employer-provided insurance doesn’t support freedom; it’s a tether.

True freedom includes the right to live without the constant anxiety of medical costs wiping out your savings or debt dictating your future. Healthcare isn’t about handouts; it’s about providing stability so people can invest back into the economy, start businesses, and support their families without health being the gamble. And, for anyone who worries that government-provided healthcare will diminish job incentives, consider this: better health creates a stronger workforce. If corporations in the 1950s promised health benefits to attract talent, why shouldn’t we raise the standard and make healthcare a guarantee in 2024?

The decline in union power didn’t start with the social programs of the ’60s. It began with policies favoring corporate interests and outsourcing that undercut bargaining power. Imagine if more workers had health security—unions might have thrived even more, able to negotiate for better wages without the baggage of healthcare coverage in the mix.

The call for universal healthcare isn’t about ‘waiting on the government’—it’s about finally catching up to the rest of the developed world on a moral and economic level. This isn’t about ideology. It’s about progress that supports every worker, every family, and the country as a whole. It’s about keeping our society healthy, independent, and future-focused.

Alright, let’s dig in. First off, trapping Americans in jobs just for healthcare—nothing says “land of the free” quite like needing a job to go to the doctor. And yeah, the ACA was supposed to help, but if you don’t fit a very specific profile, “affordable” ends up meaning “still too expensive.” Great, right?

Now, sure, companies started offering healthcare back when WWII wage caps pushed them to get creative. But let’s not act like corporate America wasn’t thrilled about finding a way to keep people glued to their jobs. This isn’t exactly just the government at work—corporations ran with it because it kept them in control of our healthcare access.

As for union decline, it didn’t need social programs to speed things along. Policies that boosted corporate interests and outsourcing did plenty of damage all on their own. Let’s face it, the same system that’s supposedly about “free markets” has always been quick to stack the deck for big business, especially when it came to crushing union power.

Now, on universal healthcare, you’d think the idea of catching up with the rest of the developed world wouldn’t be this radical. Other countries with single-payer systems aren’t exactly dealing with an exodus of doctors. In fact, our system’s doing a fine job pushing people out on its own—with insane burnout, mountains of admin work, and profit-focused care.

And yeah, universal healthcare would need investment and planning. But the fact that it’s challenging isn’t a reason to write it off. It’s the reason to start now, unless we’re okay just kicking the can down the road indefinitely while every other developed nation manages to make it work.

They're not actually that much more expensive than they used to be. One part of why it seems that way is inflation, I think the best show of that is that new play-scale millennium falcon (the alt-universe black one) when accounting for inflation it's not only cheaper than all the other play-scale falcons going back to 2011, it has more pieces (albeit smaller ones on average due to the more complex builds). Not every set is going to be like this of course, but on average, price per piece hasn't been rising dramatically or anything.

The other reason is their adults-welcome push, which I think started even before that branding. That meant bigger sets that are aimed at people who either have a lot of money to spend on it OR people who buy lego once or twice a year. It's annoying, but some of the adult sets are pretty good value, the botanical ones are great for example.

So too many big sets combined with inflation gives the impression that lego is wildly more expensive when it used to be when it's really not the case.

Honestly lego pricing is pretty all over that place sometimes, so it's best to look at it on a set by set basis, sometimes a set will be horribly priced while another will be priced quite cheap. For some of the best value I'd look into sets and themes aimed at kids. Lego city and friends have some great sets that are amazing value. The recent city construction vehicles look great and are priced really well. Even licenced themes are priced pretty good sometimes, like the falcon I mentioned earlier but a great example is the new fortnite sets, they are priced extremely competitively.

Oh no! I definitely read it, I just don't believe it for a second. Lego has quadrupled in price in the last 10 years.

Not with the “shrinking” qualifier. Growing by half would be N * 1.5 with N being the starting size. You take half of the starting size, then add it to N. Shrinking by half would be N * 0.5. You take half of the starting size, then subtract it from N. What you’re trying to do is introduce division for some reason. N / .50 would indeed grow it, but that’s not what’s happening here.

You're being too pessimistic thinking this way. An awful of of cancers (the majority now) are radically treatable, preventable or effectively eradicated and it's getting better quite rapidly.

Your vaccine analogy is apt, as there are many viral diseases with no vaccine, or vaccines which are less effective or complex and expensive to administer to large populations. Viral disease is diverse, as is cancer and medicine faces those challenges with diverse treatments. 

You're right to point to the many past successes and potential future successes of vaccines, but you should think similarly for cancer.

It's simply a reflection of what cancer is (or any broad group of diseases) that the concept of a single cure doesn't really make sense and is extremely unlikely, however it's not necessary. Having a range of treatments to treat a range of cancers is appropriate.

Incidentally, vaccines can prevent cancer. The HPV vaccine combined with routine screening is expected to eradicate cervix cancer entirely in the vaccinated population. The rate of cervix cancer in women born after 1996 in the UK is expected to be 90% less than older generations. This this is limited to HPV-related cancers obviously.
